PICTURED FROM L TO R ARE BARRON WITHERSPOON, DAVID TAYLOR, TAMARA THOMAS, MONICA TURNER, DR.

0-chunk_2_1255895032170866736.chunk_text: PICTURED FROM L TO R ARE BARRON WITHERSPOON, DAVID TAYLOR, TAMARA THOMAS, MONICA TURNER, DR. MICHAEL L. LOMAX, SHELLY MCNAMARA, PAUL GAMA, AMY ROBERTI, CRYSTAL HARRELL AND TERENCE MOORE. SPEAKER OF THE U.

0-chunk_3_7227682463267448965.chunk_text: SPEAKER OF THE U. S. HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES NANCY PELOSI ATTENDED THE NATIONAL UNCF “A MIND IS…” GALA IN HONOR OF HER COLLEAGUES U. S.

0-chunk_4_-553386889480700104.chunk_text: S. REP. JOHN LEWIS D GA AND U. S.

0-chunk_5_-2855180029761557036.chunk_text: S. REP. JAMES CLYBURNE D SC , WHO BOTH RECEIVED THE UNCF FREDERICK D. PATTERSON AWARD DURING THE EVENT.

0-chunk_6_-2117048643214359546.chunk_text: PATTERSON AWARD DURING THE EVENT. DURING THE CELEBRATION, DR. MICHAEL LOMAX ANNOUNCED THE RETIREMENT OF RUST COLLEGE PRESIDENT DR. DAVID L.

0-chunk_7_5845170119350399226.chunk_text: DAVID L. BECKLEY, WHO LEFT HIS POST AFTER 26 YEARS AT THE TOP OF THE HOLLY SPRINGS, MS, INSTITUTION. THE UNCF FREDERICK D. PATTERSON AWARD WAS PRESENTED TO U.

0-chunk_10_1712546706210362684.chunk_text: ACCEPTING ON THEIR BEHALF WERE MIGNON CLYBURNE, REP. CLYBURNE’S DAUGHTER, AND U. S. REP.

0-chunk_11_7708832171551077372.chunk_text: REP. ANDRÉ CARSON D IN . ALSO ON STAGE FROM LEFT TO RIGHT WERE DR. MICHAEL LOMAX, UNCF BOARD MEMBER MILTON H.

0-chunk_12_6779432582510014109.chunk_text: MICHAEL LOMAX, UNCF BOARD MEMBER MILTON H. JONES JR. , SPEAKER NANCY PELOSI, UNCF BOARD MEMBER AND TALLADEGA COLLEGE PRESIDENT BILLY HAWKINS, FORMER FISK UNIVERSITY PRESIDENT DR. KEVIN ROME AND SHAW UNIVERSITY PRESIDENT DR.

0-chunk_13_-4851796093290181021.chunk_text: KEVIN ROME AND SHAW UNIVERSITY PRESIDENT DR. PAULETTE DILLARD. W hen Dr. Frederick D.

0-chunk_14_9200862298266715819.chunk_text: Frederick D. Patterson, Mary McLeod Bethune, John D. Rockefeller and other legendary American education, business and social leaders came together in 1944 in New York City to incorporate the United Negro College Fund in April 1944, their vision was to fuel historically Black colleges and universities HBCUs across the United States far into the future—all the while not knowing how long the mission would last or how many lives it would touch. Originally, UNCF supported 27 colleges.

0-chunk_15_691052719690169467.chunk_text: Originally, UNCF supported 27 colleges. The goal was simple—make it easier for the smaller, underfunded HBCUs to continue to educate a largely Black constituency that had few to no other college options because African American contributions to American society were sorely needed— and at all levels. And UNCF was a success from the very beginning. The �rst annual campaign in 1944 raised $765,000—an amount three times more than what was raised by the individual colleges through separate fundraising campaigns in the previous year.

0-chunk_16_655283711932801542.chunk_text: The �rst annual campaign in 1944 raised $765,000—an amount three times more than what was raised by the individual colleges through separate fundraising campaigns in the previous year. In their wildest dreams, UNCF’s founders could not have foreseen the success of this fundamentally big American idea that became a reality. In 2019, UNCF—having stood the test of time—turned 75. Since those heady early days, many things have changed.

0-chunk_17_3342085274656658909.chunk_text: Since those heady early days, many things have changed. From 27 member institutions to 37. From a few thousand students annually attending its HBCUs to 55,000. Add to that, an additional 5,000 plus students who get scholarships who aren’t attending UNCF member HBCUs, and UNCF annually supports more than 60,000 students in total.

0-chunk_18_-6267827159549272070.chunk_text: Add to that, an additional 5,000 plus students who get scholarships who aren’t attending UNCF member HBCUs, and UNCF annually supports more than 60,000 students in total. > YOUNG MEN FROM THE KIPP DC – COLLEGE PREPARATORY ACADEMY PUBLIC CHARTER SCHOOL GAVE A SPECIAL LIVE PERFORMANCE FROM THE BROADWAY PLAY, “NEWSIES,” DURING THE 76TH NATIONAL UNCF “A MIND IS…” GALA. To commemorate the year, UNCF launched a series of 75th anniversary events all year long, raising awareness about how it has worked tirelessly to enable as many students to get to and through college as possible. UNCF conducted 63 events, raising an unprecedented $14 million in unrestricted revenue.

0-chunk_19_1550438252476489305.chunk_text: UNCF conducted 63 events, raising an unprecedented $14 million in unrestricted revenue. That amounts to more than 8,000 students earning their degrees during the most recent academic year. Remarkable, one might say. But it doesn’t end there.

0-chunk_20_-650745217061068339.chunk_text: But it doesn’t end there. In its 75 years, UNCF has raised over $5 billion in donations—gifts—from supporters, both large and small, across the spectrum of the United States. And through those billions of gifted dollars, it has helped more than half a million students earn their college degrees. Quite an accomplishment—and quite a reason to come together to celebrate.

0-chunk_21_3757604104152224159.chunk_text: Quite an accomplishment—and quite a reason to come together to celebrate. So, on March 5, 2020, UNCF o�cially wrapped up its 75th anniversary celebration e�orts during its National “A Mind Is…” Gala, in Washington, DC, at the Wardman Park Marriott Hotel, recognizing all that has been and launching a vision of what is yet to come. Among the many tributes and honorees supporting UNCF over its decades of work were the Top Ladies of Distinction, Procter and Gamble and Lilly Endowment, Inc. Also marking the event were two signi�cant tributes to national civil rights leaders and federal lawmakers, U.

0-chunk_22_-6912107541215984674.chunk_text: Also marking the event were two signi�cant tributes to national civil rights leaders and federal lawmakers, U. S. Rep. John Lewis D GA and U.

0-chunk_23_2024419597879546918.chunk_text: John Lewis D GA and U. S. Rep. James Clyburn D SC .

0-chunk_24_3977894722967813300.chunk_text: James Clyburn D SC . Speaker of the House of Representatives Nancy Pelosi attended the event, showing her respect for both UNCF and the honorees. “It is a great honor to join the friends and leaders of UNCF to recognize two of our nation’s most extraordinary civil rights champions, Whip James Clyburn and the Conscience of the Congress, Congressman John Lewis, in this year that marks 55 years since the march from Selma,” said Speaker Pelosi. “As we observe this milestone and celebrate 76 years of UNCF’s outstanding success, we must all recommit to the �ght to expanding opportunities and advancing justice for communities of color and for all Americans, and to building the more perfect union that generations of courageous Americans have sacri�ced to build.

0-chunk_25_1712562978858334127.chunk_text: “As we observe this milestone and celebrate 76 years of UNCF’s outstanding success, we must all recommit to the �ght to expanding opportunities and advancing justice for communities of color and for all Americans, and to building the more perfect union that generations of courageous Americans have sacri�ced to build. ” To punctuate 75 years and the national commemoration, UNCF President and CEO Dr. Michael Lomax added his thoughts to the evening. “As the story goes, the great African American poet Langston Hughes—another HBCU graduate—was working as a busboy here at the Wardman Park Hotel when he was discovered in 1925 by poet Vachel Lindsay.

0-chunk_26_-9179528467854519268.chunk_text: “As the story goes, the great African American poet Langston Hughes—another HBCU graduate—was working as a busboy here at the Wardman Park Hotel when he was discovered in 1925 by poet Vachel Lindsay. “So you might say that it is poetic justice that 95 years later, an organization dedicated to educating African American poets—and teachers and scientists and businesspeople—would have raised more than $5 billion in 75 years, would have helped graduate more than 500,000 students, and would be awarding more than 10,000 scholarships a year worth $100 million. “And would be a powerful and laser focused advocate for its 37 private HBCUs, and one of the nation’s most e�ective advocates for all HBCUs. “Or that taken in aggregate, HBCUs would become an economic engine generating almost $15 billion in annual economic impact, and $130 billion in lifetime earnings for each HBCU graduating class?

0-chunk_27_-5631232692929447210.chunk_text: “Or that taken in aggregate, HBCUs would become an economic engine generating almost $15 billion in annual economic impact, and $130 billion in lifetime earnings for each HBCU graduating class? “I think Langston Hughes would have been proud. And we hope that all of you are too. ” So, with more than 75 years of remarkable history, accomplishments and impact under its belt, UNCF now leans into the future, knowing that it remains the vital, necessary higher education dynamo that began all those years ago as a big American idea—an idea that has stuck with us because it works, and it does what it says it will do: empower needy, deserving students to get and through college successfully.

0-chunk_final_-5631232692929447210.chunk_text: “Or that taken in aggregate, HBCUs would become an economic engine generating almost $15 billion in annual economic impact, and $130 billion in lifetime earnings for each HBCU graduating class? “I think Langston Hughes would have been proud. And we hope that all of you are too. ” So, with more than 75 years of remarkable history, accomplishments and impact under its belt, UNCF now leans into the future, knowing that it remains the vital, necessary higher education dynamo that began all those years ago as a big American idea—an idea that has stuck with us because it works, and it does what it says it will do: empower needy, deserving students to get and through college successfully.

2-chunk_11_-6372880701279563223.chunk_text: A computer engineering master's degree dives deep into computer hardware, software, networks, and architecture. Graduate study can open the doors to research work, and introduce you to professors and peers who are leaders in the field. If you aspire to work with artificial intelligence or robotics, write or test software, build hardware, or develop systems, this degree can help you achieve your ambition. It can also allow you to earn more money.

2-chunk_12_7943156992516516602.chunk_text: It can also allow you to earn more money. According to Payscale https://www.payscale.com/research/US/Degree=Master_of_Science_(MS)%2C_Computer_Engineering_(CE)/Salary), people with a master's in computer engineering earned an average annual salary of $108,000 as of November 2023 — at least $12,000 more a year than those with a bachelor's degree in the field. Explore the guide below to learn more about the top computer engineering master's degrees, including admissions requirements, career options, and answers to the most frequently asked questions. Popular Online Programs

2-chunk_13_1455364977202041782.chunk_text: Popular Online Programs Learn about start dates, transferring credits, availability of financial aid, and more by contacting the universities below. https://www.computerscience.org/degrees/masters/computer-engineering Top Computer Engineering Master's Programs

2-chunk_14_-2990039567297911129.chunk_text: Top Computer Engineering Master's Programs How We Rank Colleges And Bootcamps ComputerScience. org ranks computer science degree programs at the associate, bachelor’s, master’s, and doctoral levels.

2-chunk_15_6307663971179156351.chunk_text: org ranks computer science degree programs at the associate, bachelor’s, master’s, and doctoral levels. We also rank bootcamps and certificate programs. Our top priority is making sure you find the best possible fit for your education. We use up to date national statistics and focus on factors like return on investment, academic quality, and affordability.

2-chunk_16_6987372208806310460.chunk_text: We use up to date national statistics and focus on factors like return on investment, academic quality, and affordability. Take a closer look at our rankings on our rankings methodology page https://www.computerscience.org/methodology/). https://www.computerscience.org/degrees/masters/computer-engineering Why Get a Computer Engineering Master's Degree?

2-chunk_17_-5995440006936415439.chunk_text: Why Get a Computer Engineering Master's Degree? Computer engineering started in the 1940s when Dr. John Vincent Atanasoff, a professor at Iowa State College, and his student Clifford Berry built the first electronic digital computer. Formal computer engineering education, however, did not launch until 1971, when Case Western Reserve offered the first accredited computer engineering degree in the U.

2-chunk_18_-1102045857488144898.chunk_text: Formal computer engineering education, however, did not launch until 1971, when Case Western Reserve offered the first accredited computer engineering degree in the U. S. Today, more than 78,000 computer hardware engineers work in research, development, and manufacturing settings across the U. S.

2-chunk_19_2003791841497623260.chunk_text: S. In 2022, the Bureau of Labor Statistics https://www.bls.gov/ooh/architecture-and-engineering/computer-hardware-engineers.htm#tab-1) BLS projected that the field would add 3,600 new jobs by 2032. Hardware engineers earn a median annual wage of $132,360 — almost three times the median salary for all occupations. Computer engineering professionals are building the world of tomorrow.

2-chunk_20_4404511770605041945.chunk_text: Computer engineering professionals are building the world of tomorrow. A computer engineering degree https://www.computerscience.org/degrees/computer-engineering-programs/) can also prepare you for a career as a network architect, software engineer, information systems manager, or research scientist. These fast growing, high paying fields can provide meaningful and exciting work for problem solvers and critical thinkers. While a graduate certificate or bootcamp may be faster, a master's degree in computer engineering offers several benefits:

2-chunk_21_3259236057181735088.chunk_text: While a graduate certificate or bootcamp may be faster, a master's degree in computer engineering offers several benefits: Expand Your Knowledge Base : If you work in technology design, you should be able to apply what you learn in a computer engineering master's degree right away. Your knowledge may help you be more effective in your current role or transition to a new career. Work in a Complex Subfield : A master's program can help you qualify for math intensive jobs, to work with autonomous machines, or do chip or register transfer level design.

2-chunk_22_8449806388204828177.chunk_text: Work in a Complex Subfield : A master's program can help you qualify for math intensive jobs, to work with autonomous machines, or do chip or register transfer level design. A degree can also prepare you for a director or senior director role. Prepare for a Doctorate : If you aspire to teach at the college level or perform original research in the field, you need a doctorate. A master's degree can equip you for next level study.

2-chunk_23_-2402056900591453990.chunk_text: A master's degree can equip you for next level study. What to Expect From Computer Engineering Graduate Programs As the world grows more digitized, employers, from hospitals to national security agencies, need innovative experts who can create groundbreaking technology to advance human flourishing. Computer engineering graduate programs can help you learn how to build the smart devices that connect the modern world.

2-chunk_24_-9040980362566148720.chunk_text: Computer engineering graduate programs can help you learn how to build the smart devices that connect the modern world. As a student, you can learn about topics from artificial intelligence https://www.computerscience.org/resources/artificial-intelligence/) to cybersecurity, but your focus will rest on designing, scaling, and programming computer systems. Earning a master's degree in this field usually takes two years if you enroll in 6 12 credits each semester. Courses could include advanced computer architecture, object oriented design, and network centric systems.

2-chunk_25_-2168684195260771441.chunk_text: Courses could include advanced computer architecture, object oriented design, and network centric systems. You may also have a chance to research and produce a thesis before graduating. Total costs vary widely between programs, but it's a good idea to plan on spending more than $35,000 on your degree. The good news is that you may find scholarships and discounts to help you meet those costs.

2-chunk_26_-3113943851323006719.chunk_text: The good news is that you may find scholarships and discounts to help you meet those costs. Upon graduation, you can pursue a career in computer chip design, aerospace engineering, biomedical engineering, or machine learning and AI https://www.computerscience.org/resources/learn-ai/). Admission Requirements Admission to a computer engineering master's degree generally requires the following:

2-chunk_27_8652786704375350600.chunk_text: Admission to a computer engineering master's degree generally requires the following: Bachelor's Degree https://www.computerscience.org/degrees/bachelors/computer-engineering/)**:**You need a four year undergraduate degree from an accredited institution. Schools often expect a technology or engineering related major. Minimum GPA: Many graduate programs require a 3.

2-chunk_28_5382428154045254456.chunk_text: Minimum GPA: Many graduate programs require a 3. 0 or better for admission. GRE Scores: Post COVID, many master's programs have waived the GRE requirement, but others still expect you to submit scores. Prerequisites: You should have taken adequate preparatory coursework in computer science and electrical engineering.

2-chunk_29_-5624189576275662615.chunk_text: Prerequisites: You should have taken adequate preparatory coursework in computer science and electrical engineering. Some schools may offer bridge courses if you need them. Degree and Specialization Options A school might offer a master of science in computer engineering, a master of engineering in computer engineering, or even both.

2-chunk_30_4676380705392457232.chunk_text: A school might offer a master of science in computer engineering, a master of engineering in computer engineering, or even both. These two degrees, while related, are not the same. The master of science emphasizes research and theory, while the master of engineering leans toward real world application and practice. A computer engineering master's degree may include specific concentrations such as computer security, AI/ML systems, intelligent physical systems, or devices and nanofab.

2-chunk_31_841246865650856325.chunk_text: A computer engineering master's degree may include specific concentrations such as computer security, AI/ML systems, intelligent physical systems, or devices and nanofab. You can choose a concentration based on your career goals and academic interests. https://www.computerscience.org/degrees/masters/computer-engineering Popular Computer Engineering Courses

2-chunk_32_6697501716356867193.chunk_text: Popular Computer Engineering Courses As you explore computer engineering master's degrees, you may find a variety of courses offered in different programs. While each school's curriculum is unique, computer engineering generally includes courses like the ones below: Digital Signal Processing : This course builds on a background in linear systems analysis.

2-chunk_33_-6493856610547303242.chunk_text: Digital Signal Processing : This course builds on a background in linear systems analysis. Students explore fast algorithms, quantization effects, discrete time signals and systems, and digital filter design and implementation. Embedded Systems and Machine Learning : Students discover how to apply machine learning to embedded applications. Topics in this course include edge computing, the Internet of Things, model compression, latency, data reuse, and hardware codesign for machine learning.

2-chunk_34_-7814147238433698233.chunk_text: Topics in this course include edge computing, the Internet of Things, model compression, latency, data reuse, and hardware codesign for machine learning. Biometrics : Learners explore why computers and networks need security measures to safeguard sensitive data. The course covers the theory, tools, and techniques of biometric security design. Introduction to System on Chip Design : Topics in this course include cell based system on chip design, pipelining, top down design flow, and software hardware co design and co simulation.

2-chunk_35_8667934860443088775.chunk_text: Introduction to System on Chip Design : Topics in this course include cell based system on chip design, pipelining, top down design flow, and software hardware co design and co simulation. https://www.computerscience.org/degrees/masters/computer-engineering How Much Will Graduate School Cost? The average computer science master's degree costs $18,274 per year, according to the National Council for Education Statistics https://nces.ed.gov/datalab/powerstats/158-national-postsecondary-student-aid-study-2020-graduate-students/averages-medians-percents) NCES .

2-chunk_36_1951360765360216419.chunk_text: The average computer science master's degree costs $18,274 per year, according to the National Council for Education Statistics https://nces.ed.gov/datalab/powerstats/158-national-postsecondary-student-aid-study-2020-graduate-students/averages-medians-percents) NCES . However, that average stands in the center of a wide range of potential costs. Some schools charge less than $200 per credit, but others go up to almost $2,000. Factors such as a school's prestige and whether it receives public support can affect the price.

2-chunk_37_-1984153203222173316.chunk_text: Factors such as a school's prestige and whether it receives public support can affect the price. Online students may also pay technology fees or other add on costs. You do not necessarily have to pay all your expenses out of pocket. Approximately 61% of surveyed online learners receive financial aid https://www.computerscience.org/scholarships/) such as scholarships, discounts, or employer support.

2-chunk_38_6219724177405057656.chunk_text: Approximately 61% of surveyed online learners receive financial aid https://www.computerscience.org/scholarships/) such as scholarships, discounts, or employer support. Learn more about how to pay for a degree https://www.computerscience.org/resources/how-to-pay-for-a-degree/)** Explore your scholarship and financial aid options https://www.computerscience.org/scholarships/) Find companies that may pay for your degree https://www.computerscience.org/resources/companies-that-pay-for-college/)**

2-chunk_39_7840502187448839709.chunk_text: Find companies that may pay for your degree https://www.computerscience.org/resources/companies-that-pay-for-college/)** Discover scholarship programs for women in tech https://www.computerscience.org/scholarships-women/)** https://www.computerscience.org/degrees/masters/computer-engineering Jobs for Master's in Computer Engineering Graduates

2-chunk_40_-8625908300257303021.chunk_text: Jobs for Master's in Computer Engineering Graduates Earning a computer engineering master's degree can position you for engaging, high paying positions in technology. Consider the following careers: Hardware Engineer https://www.computerscience.org/careers/computer-hardware-engineer/)

2-chunk_41_-6467843540875172250.chunk_text: Hardware Engineer https://www.computerscience.org/careers/computer-hardware-engineer/) Hardware engineers build routers, networks, processors, circuit boards, and memory devices for computer systems. Often working in research, development, and design companies, these professionals may develop entirely new systems or devise processors for devices containing internet ready systems, like cars, appliances, or medical equipment. Hardware engineers need a strong background in computer science and electrical engineering.

2-chunk_42_-7864752100128943600.chunk_text: Hardware engineers need a strong background in computer science and electrical engineering. Required Education: Bachelor's degree or higher Median Annual Salary: $132,360 https://www.bls.gov/ooh/architecture-and-engineering/computer-hardware-engineers.htm) Job Outlook 2022 32 : 5% https://www.bls.gov/ooh/architecture-and-engineering/computer-hardware-engineers.htm)

2-chunk_43_-5891732903079342712.chunk_text: Job Outlook 2022 32 : 5% https://www.bls.gov/ooh/architecture-and-engineering/computer-hardware-engineers.htm) Software Developer https://www.computerscience.org/careers/software-developer/) Software developers envision, design, and create computer programs and applications. Usually working under the direction of a software engineer, these professionals may create user specific operating systems, such as games or commercial software.

2-chunk_44_-4487689544737114022.chunk_text: Usually working under the direction of a software engineer, these professionals may create user specific operating systems, such as games or commercial software. Software developers typically need a bachelor's degree, but many employers may require a master's degree. Strong coding skills are a must have for this profession. Required Education: Bachelor's degree or higher

2-chunk_45_-8558535732507111492.chunk_text: Required Education: Bachelor's degree or higher Median/Average Annual Salary: $127,260 https://www.bls.gov/ooh/computer-and-information-technology/software-developers.htm#tab-5) Job Outlook 2022 32 : 26% https://www.bls.gov/ooh/computer-and-information-technology/software-developers.htm#tab-6) Computer Programmer https://www.computerscience.org/careers/computer-programmer/)

2-chunk_46_6926594542541212133.chunk_text: Computer Programmer https://www.computerscience.org/careers/computer-programmer/) Computer programmers write, edit, and test the codes that run computer applications and software. These professionals often have expertise in multiple coding languages. AI's automation of routine work is shrinking the need for computer programmers.

2-chunk_47_-7439565043788580106.chunk_text: AI's automation of routine work is shrinking the need for computer programmers. Nevertheless, AI cannot do the strategic planning, analysis, or project development that the field requires. Required Education: Bachelor's degree or higher Median Annual Salary: $97,800 https://www.bls.gov/ooh/computer-and-information-technology/computer-programmers.htm)

2-chunk_48_8633515747952933438.chunk_text: Median Annual Salary: $97,800 https://www.bls.gov/ooh/computer-and-information-technology/computer-programmers.htm) Job Outlook 2022 32 : 11% https://www.bls.gov/ooh/computer-and-information-technology/computer-programmers.htm) Computer Network Architects https://www.computerscience.org/careers/information-technology-architect/) Sometimes called network engineers, computer network architects design and manage computer networks, including local area networks, wide area networks, and intranets.

2-chunk_49_8201548151772457013.chunk_text: Sometimes called network engineers, computer network architects design and manage computer networks, including local area networks, wide area networks, and intranets. These professionals often have experience as systems administrators, database administrators, or computer systems analysts. Network architects may need industry certifications in addition to experience and a relevant degree. Required Education: Bachelor's degree or higher

2-chunk_50_-7931863992815420871.chunk_text: Required Education: Bachelor's degree or higher Median/Average Annual Salary: $126,900 https://www.bls.gov/ooh/computer-and-information-technology/computer-network-architects.htm) Job Outlook 2022 32 : 4% https://www.bls.gov/ooh/computer-and-information-technology/computer-network-architects.htm) Computer Information Researcher https://www.computerscience.org/careers/computer-information-researcher/)

2-chunk_51_-2616776779503708517.chunk_text: Computer Information Researcher https://www.computerscience.org/careers/computer-information-researcher/) Working in government agencies, universities, and computer design firms, researchers create new computer systems or improve existing ones. They can specialize in areas such as robotics or programming. These innovative specialists may solve problems in medicine, business, or science.

2-chunk_52_-8607395375638278801.chunk_text: These innovative specialists may solve problems in medicine, business, or science. Some researchers also serve as postsecondary professors. Required Education: Master's degree or higher Median Annual Salary: $136,620 https://www.bls.gov/ooh/computer-and-information-technology/computer-and-information-research-scientists.htm)

2-chunk_53_-1138203429661953739.chunk_text: Median Annual Salary: $136,620 https://www.bls.gov/ooh/computer-and-information-technology/computer-and-information-research-scientists.htm) Job Outlook 2022 32 : 23% https://www.bls.gov/ooh/computer-and-information-technology/computer-and-information-research-scientists.htm) https://www.computerscience.org/degrees/masters/computer-engineering Choosing the Right Computer Engineering Graduate Program

2-chunk_54_4490172786030957670.chunk_text: Choosing the Right Computer Engineering Graduate Program To maximize your learning experience, choose an accredited computer engineering program that is affordable, convenient, customizable, and local. Accredited: An institutionally accredited school gives you access to financial aid and career opportunities that non accredited institutions cannot match. Program accreditation does not apply to graduate level CS degrees.

2-chunk_55_-2501666044993037518.chunk_text: Program accreditation does not apply to graduate level CS degrees. Affordable: Look beyond the price tag. Does your potential school offer scholarships, locked in tuition, free textbooks, discounts, or other incentives? Convenient: Many students find asynchronous courses and shorter terms help them finish their requirements on time while maintaining work, family, or community obligations.

2-chunk_56_-3185802212324741065.chunk_text: Convenient: Many students find asynchronous courses and shorter terms help them finish their requirements on time while maintaining work, family, or community obligations. Customizable: Can you choose a concentration relevant to your career goals? Does your program incorporate professional certifications, micro credentials, digital badges, or trade skills certificates? Local: Online education lets you choose from schools worldwide, but learning locally may be your best option.

2-chunk_57_9096746873730227335.chunk_text: Local: Online education lets you choose from schools worldwide, but learning locally may be your best option. If you live near campus, you can participate in on site laboratories, special events, and job fairs specific to computer engineering. Should You Get Your Master's Degree Online? In the fall of 2021, the NCES reported https://nces.ed.gov/fastfacts/display.asp?id=80) that 56% of graduate learners were studying online, and 40% were earning their entire degrees by distance education.

2-chunk_58_5392663444074641974.chunk_text: In the fall of 2021, the NCES reported https://nces.ed.gov/fastfacts/display.asp?id=80) that 56% of graduate learners were studying online, and 40% were earning their entire degrees by distance education. The field is burgeoning, but is online education effective? Research says yes — with some qualifications. Wiley's 2023 study of online learners https://universityservices.wiley.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/06/202306-VOL2023-report-WUNI-final.pdf) found that 91% of online students viewed their educational experience positively, and 92% of graduates said they had achieved a positive outcome because of their degree.

2-chunk_59_955145641402120390.chunk_text: Wiley's 2023 study of online learners https://universityservices.wiley.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/06/202306-VOL2023-report-WUNI-final.pdf) found that 91% of online students viewed their educational experience positively, and 92% of graduates said they had achieved a positive outcome because of their degree. Still, 18% of learners planned to switch to a campus based program, primarily because they missed the peer to peer interaction. Discover more paths to learning computer science: https://www.computerscience.org/degrees/masters/computer-engineering

2-chunk_60_2704326511676621537.chunk_text: https://www.computerscience.org/degrees/masters/computer-engineering More Questions About Master's in Computer Engineering Programs What can you do with a master's in computer engineering? With a master's in computer engineering, you can pursue a career as a hardware engineer, network architect, cybersecurity analyst, or information systems manager.

2-chunk_61_7977448679588860877.chunk_text: With a master's in computer engineering, you can pursue a career as a hardware engineer, network architect, cybersecurity analyst, or information systems manager. This degree can also position you for a Ph. D. and a subsequent career in teaching or research.

2-chunk_62_-1674525248332785678.chunk_text: and a subsequent career in teaching or research. Is a master's in computer engineering the same as a computer science master's? Computer engineering and computer science are related but different subjects. Computer engineering focuses on building hardware systems, while computer science is a holistic field concerned with theory and analysis.

2-chunk_63_-3714194751268120941.chunk_text: Computer engineering focuses on building hardware systems, while computer science is a holistic field concerned with theory and analysis. How long does it take to finish a computer engineering master's? Most computer engineering master's programs take two years to finish. However, not all students work on the same timeline.

2-chunk_64_-72269872649737379.chunk_text: However, not all students work on the same timeline. Part time learners may need more time, but accelerated BA/MS students might earn both degrees in five years. Is going to graduate school for computer engineering worth it? In November 2023, Payscale reported https://www.payscale.com/research/US/Degree=Master_of_Science_(MS)%2C_Computer_Engineering_(CE)/Salary) that people with a master's in computer engineering earned an average annual salary of $108,000.

2-chunk_65_2925098616962846321.chunk_text: In November 2023, Payscale reported https://www.payscale.com/research/US/Degree=Master_of_Science_(MS)%2C_Computer_Engineering_(CE)/Salary) that people with a master's in computer engineering earned an average annual salary of $108,000. People with a BS in computer engineering earned an average of $96,000. According to the NCES https://nces.ed.gov/datalab/powerstats/158-national-postsecondary-student-aid-study-2020-graduate-students/averages-medians-percents), the average CS master's degree costs $18,274 annually. Assuming a total cost of $37,000 for a two year degree and average salaries before and after earning your master's, you could realize a positive ROI in 25 months.

2-chunk_66_-3730436343426622092.chunk_text: Assuming a total cost of $37,000 for a two year degree and average salaries before and after earning your master's, you could realize a positive ROI in 25 months. 3-chunk_41_-5386743709338466693.chunk_text: Powered aviation began in Dayton. Orville and Wilbur Wright https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wright_brothers "Wright brothers" were the first to construct and demonstrate powered flight. Although the first flight was in Kitty Hawk, North Carolina https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kitty_Hawk,_North_Carolina "Kitty Hawk, North Carolina" , their Wright Flyer was built in and returned to Dayton for improvements and further flights at Huffman Field https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Huffman_Field "Huffman Field" , a cow pasture eight miles 13 km northeast of Dayton, near the current Wright Patterson Air Force Base. When the government tried to move development to Langley Field https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Langley_Air_Force_Base "Langley Air Force Base" in southern Virginia, six Dayton businessmen including Edward A.

3-chunk_42_-8045675016913767331.chunk_text: When the government tried to move development to Langley Field https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Langley_Air_Force_Base "Langley Air Force Base" in southern Virginia, six Dayton businessmen including Edward A. Deeds, formed the Dayton Wright Airplane Company in Moraine and established a flying field. Deeds also opened a field to the north in the flood plain of the Great Miami River between the confluences of that river, the Stillwater River, and the Mad River near downtown Dayton . Later named McCook Field https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/McCook_Field "McCook Field" for Alexander McDowell McCook, an American Civil War general, this became the Army Signal Corps' primary aviation research and training location.

3-chunk_43_6208471423170522718.chunk_text: Later named McCook Field https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/McCook_Field "McCook Field" for Alexander McDowell McCook, an American Civil War general, this became the Army Signal Corps' primary aviation research and training location. Wilbur Wright also purchased land near Huffman prairie to continue their research. During World War I, the Army purchased 40 acres adjacent to Huffman Prairie for the Fairfield Aviation General Supply Depot. As airplanes developed more capability, they needed more runway space than McCook could offer, and a new location was sought.

3-chunk_44_-6845751737841524435.chunk_text: As airplanes developed more capability, they needed more runway space than McCook could offer, and a new location was sought. 3-chunk_51_-7319012454497404872.chunk_text: 29 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio cite note 29 Between the 1940s and the 1970s, the city saw significant growth in suburban areas from population migration. Advancements in architecture also contributed to the suburban boom.

3-chunk_52_5878637483746670084.chunk_text: Advancements in architecture also contributed to the suburban boom. 3-chunk_388_-9101583298562264925.chunk_text: The Dayton City Commission is composed of the mayor and four city commissioners. Each city commission member is elected at large on a non partisan basis for four year, overlapping terms. All policy items are decided by the city commission, which is empowered by the City Charter to pass ordinances and resolutions, adopt regulations, and appoint the city manager. The city manager is responsible for budgeting and implementing policies and initiatives.

Dayton and Montgomery County offer big city amenities with Midwestern charm and affordability. Dayton is home to the Wright Brothers https://www.destinationdayton.org/maps and info/history/wright brothers/ ,the Dayton Aviation Heritage National Historical Park https://www.destinationdayton.org/things to do/attractions/dayton aviation park/ , and the National Museum of the U.

Air Force https://www.destinationdayton.org/things to do/attractions/air force museum/ ™, the world’s largest and oldest military aviation museum and the state’s most visited free tourist attraction! 5-chunk_15_-4173621125780449032.chunk_text: Be the first. Since 1951, when MIT Lincoln Laboratory was established to build the nation’s first air defense system, the Laboratory has been applying advanced technology to problems critical to national security. In addition to an impressive record of technical innovation in communications, space surveillance, advanced electronics, and air and missile defense, today the Laboratory is also leading the way in newer areas such as cyber security, integrated sensing and decision support and homeland protection. Behind every Laboratory solution are researchers with exceptional technical abilities and imagination, developing systems from the initial concept stage, through simulation and analysis, to design and prototyping, and finally to real world demonstrations.

5-chunk_16_8650725352304245441.chunk_text: Behind every Laboratory solution are researchers with exceptional technical abilities and imagination, developing systems from the initial concept stage, through simulation and analysis, to design and prototyping, and finally to real world demonstrations. Cross disciplinary collaboration and the breadth of Lincoln Laboratory’s research enable continuous technical growth for its scientists – and they also inspire unparalleled creativity. In the past six years, MIT Lincoln Laboratory has been awarded 26 R&D 100 Awards that recognize the year’s 100 most significant innovations in technology. All positions are located in Lexington, MA.

5-chunk_39_-2248416412922094097.chunk_text: 30 The Archives and the Archivist: Sharing SWE’s Story Together In addition to being a repository of many “stories” and artifacts, the SWE archives has an interesting story of its own, intertwined with that of SWE’s archivist, Troy Eller English, who oversees the collection. 36 LGBTQ Employment Policy Caught in the Crosscurrents Influenced by political advocacy and motivated by a need to attract and retain a diverse, talented workforce, many organizations have adopted LGBTQ nondiscrimination policies.

5-chunk_40_8486385169177011910.chunk_text: Influenced by political advocacy and motivated by a need to attract and retain a diverse, talented workforce, many organizations have adopted LGBTQ nondiscrimination policies. As political and cultural dynamics shift, however, the status of these advancements may come into question. 44 Engineering the Magic of Live Entertainment The massive amount of technology that goes into live performance means that nearly every form of live entertainment needs the support of engineers.

5-chunk_41_7967006477964622203.chunk_text: The massive amount of technology that goes into live performance means that nearly every form of live entertainment needs the support of engineers. In fact, the demand for women engineers in this area is rising, presenting unique opportunities. 50 Women Engineers You Should Know Women engineers make important contributions to every aspect of contemporary life, frequently with little or no recognition.

5-chunk_42_5061080417875120579.chunk_text: Women engineers make important contributions to every aspect of contemporary life, frequently with little or no recognition. In keeping with the spirit of Women’s History Month, we present a sampling of women whose work has made a difference and who lead interesting and impactful lives while giving back to their profession and communities. Karen Horting, CAE Executive Director & CEO 44 WOMEN in STEM at the NATIONAL SECURITY AGENCY

5-chunk_77_6035857276530008989.chunk_text: DEPARTMENTS OPENING THOUGHTS > 7BACK TO TABLE OF CONTENTS SWE SPRING 2017 From year to year, the spring issue of SWE has had familiar themes.

5-chunk_78_-7135167361850805221.chunk_text: has had familiar themes. Published in March, a month that includes International Women’s Day on the 8th, plus ongoing women’s history celebrations in the United States and other countries, it’s fitting that we examine policies that affect women, as well as honor and celebrate women’s contributions. To more effectively and thoroughly cover policy and research, however, earlier this month we published an additional, special issue of the magazine. This special research issue is a “first.

5-chunk_79_-3121631775567555120.chunk_text: This special research issue is a “first. ” It is available on the SWE Magazine app, designed for mobile devices and downloadable through the App Store or Google play. To view on desktop and laptop computers, type into your browser: http://bit.ly/SWEMagSpecialIssue A print version is also available for purchase through www. Amazon.

5-chunk_80_1497183471217209922.chunk_text: Amazon. com . The special issue was released in time for SWE’s Congressional Visits day, providing background helpful to our advocacy event. But you don’t need a special time or group activity to advocate, and the special issue pro vides easy access to information that supports those efforts.

5-chunk_81_-9013451248040586804.chunk_text: But you don’t need a special time or group activity to advocate, and the special issue pro vides easy access to information that supports those efforts. A GOOD MATCH SWE’s special research issue contains the annual literature review, which had been a longtime staple of the spring issue, plus articles on specific research, such as SWE’s recent study, “Climate Control: Gender and Racial Bias in Engineering. ” Policy issues are covered in detail, including Title IX in the United States, as well as efforts in Europe and Canada, toward greater gender equity.

5-chunk_82_-3006071914239462541.chunk_text: ” Policy issues are covered in detail, including Title IX in the United States, as well as efforts in Europe and Canada, toward greater gender equity. Con ducting research with gender analysis as the basis is the topic of an especially interesting article on gendered innovations. The content of the special issue pairs well with the spring issue, though here we take a bit more celebratory tone. Women’s History Month takes place not only in the United States during March, but also in the United Kingdom and Australia.

5-chunk_83_4538880115299035019.chunk_text: Women’s History Month takes place not only in the United States during March, but also in the United Kingdom and Australia. In Canada, October is set aside to honor women’s history, highlighted by Persons Day on Oct. 18. Inter national Women’s Day, however, is celebrated throughout the world.

5-chunk_84_-2502876068012098986.chunk_text: Inter national Women’s Day, however, is celebrated throughout the world. In this issue you will find: • “Women Engineers You Should Know,” now an annual feature, embodies the spirit of Women’s History Month by honoring the contributions and lives of women who might otherwise go unrecognized. • “The Archives and the Archivist: Sharing SWE’s Story Together” takes an in depth look at the rich history found in the Soci ety’s archives, and the archivist who, for the past nine years, has carefully curated and promoted the collection. • “LGBTQ Employment Policy Caught in the Crosscurrents” is a thorough examina tion of workplace policies, resources, and personal experiences, in the backdrop of potentially shifting social and political dynamics.

5-chunk_85_-6223252899994560428.chunk_text: • “LGBTQ Employment Policy Caught in the Crosscurrents” is a thorough examina tion of workplace policies, resources, and personal experiences, in the backdrop of potentially shifting social and political dynamics. • For fun, our cover story, “Engineering the Magic of Live Entertainment,” addresses the use of technology in live entertainment and the collaboration that takes place between artists, designers, and engineers. And lastly, our upfront news department offers informative content ranging from the women of NASA who are poised to shape the frontiers of space exploration, to the massive influx of women interested in running for public office. Our Voices and Views, in the back of the book, provide personal insights and perspectives.

5-chunk_86_-2987267267317365122.chunk_text: Our Voices and Views, in the back of the book, provide personal insights and perspectives. I encourage you to spend some time with both magazines. Each offers content par ticularly relevant to women engineers, with much to absorb, reflect upon, and put to practical use. Director of Editorial & Publications anne.

5-chunk_119_1230611642574618038.chunk_text: 8 SWE SPRING 2017 BACK TO TABLE OF CONTENTS Women in the Statehouse Your article “Women in the State house” Winter 2017 was very timely in light of the current political situation. When I retired from 35 years in the aerospace industry, I became involved with the League of Women Voters of Utah.

5-chunk_120_-8985881710182808302.chunk_text: When I retired from 35 years in the aerospace industry, I became involved with the League of Women Voters of Utah. The League of Women Voters is a national organization that was formed in 1920, when women received the right to vote. It is nonpartisan and does not support candidates; rather, we study issues and develop consensus positions among our members. We then use these positions to lobby for or against legisla tive initiatives at the national or state level.

5-chunk_121_-9034301972461337071.chunk_text: We then use these positions to lobby for or against legisla tive initiatives at the national or state level. Our website is www. lwv. org .

5-chunk_122_-2977898971807113758.chunk_text: org . The League of Women Voters of Utah has recently studied and developed positions on constitutional conventions, human trafficking, indigent defense Article 6 of the Constitution , water use, sexual violence, and death with dignity. We have lobbied our legislators on these subjects and, I believe, have influenced potential legislation. Our website is

5-chunk_123_4290171458380466379.chunk_text: Our website is www. lwvutah. org

5-chunk_124_-8242137718188669321.chunk_text: org Organizations like the League of Women Voters need people we, like SWE, have many male members with STEM backgrounds to find structured processes using real data to assess pro posed legislation. People with scientific educations are rare in state legislatures and on the many commissions, commit tees, and councils the legislature creates. Traditionally, the Readers Forum has provided an opportunity to respond to articles or comment on topical issues.

5-chunk_125_-886987309070106932.chunk_text: Traditionally, the Readers Forum has provided an opportunity to respond to articles or comment on topical issues. 5-chunk_126_-4454020664992229902.chunk_text: Send comments, opinions, or observations to swemag@swe. org . Or, by regular mail to: Letters, SWE Magazine , Society of Women Engineers, 130 E. Randolph Street, Suite 3500, Chicago, Illinois 60601.

5-chunk_127_-355291049368240065.chunk_text: Randolph Street, Suite 3500, Chicago, Illinois 60601. Yet another way to engage with the material in SWE is through the Society’s social media — Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn, and Tumblr, as well as through All Together . Social media is a space that allows like minded individuals a way to discuss issues and contribute to the conversations started in SWE Magazine . Not everyone has the inclination or resources to run for and hold office, but every SWE member can be involved with state and local politics at some level.

5-chunk_128_-3410100415027869648.chunk_text: Not everyone has the inclination or resources to run for and hold office, but every SWE member can be involved with state and local politics at some level. I encourage SWE members to consider joining and contributing to organiza tions like the League of Women Voters. The education and experience of SWE members is invaluable to political organizations that want to make our community better. And, of course, be informed and vote in every local, state, and federal election!

5-chunk_129_-7271316644636401747.chunk_text: And, of course, be informed and vote in every local, state, and federal election! Sincerely, Nicola Nelson Co Legislative Director League of Women Voters of Utah Member 29872 North Salt Lake, Utah Please see our follow up, “A Force to Reckon With,” in this issue.

5-chunk_131_-3206853900722540098.chunk_text: 12 13 SWE WINTER 2017 SWE WINTER 2017 Women in the Statehouse: The Next Big Thing? 2016 was not a banner year for women in elected office. The glass ceiling for the highest office in the United States remains intact, the number of women in the U.

5-chunk_132_-121197208251492342.chunk_text: The glass ceiling for the highest office in the United States remains intact, the number of women in the U. S. Congress is unchanged, and the number of women governors decreased by one. At the state level, however, change is in the air.

5-chunk_133_-2912332906210201637.chunk_text: At the state level, however, change is in the air. By Meredith Holmes, SWE Contributor While the United States’ attention was fixed on presidential politics, a record number of women ran for state legislative office and won their primaries. There were 2,644 major party, female nominees in 44 states.

5-chunk_134_8792139717115485805.chunk_text: There were 2,644 major party, female nominees in 44 states. This included 2,152 nominees for statehouse seats and 492 nominees for state senate seats. The previous record was set in 2010, when the total number of female state legislative nominees was 2,537. When women run, they win as often as men do.

5-chunk_135_4734852646197394091.chunk_text: When women run, they win as often as men do. Historically, the more female nominees, the more women in office. So there was reason to expect that 2016 would see a significant increase in the number of women in statehouses nationwide. But at press time, with some races still undecided, it appeared that number had barely budged.

5-chunk_136_-3684481967838583327.chunk_text: But at press time, with some races still undecided, it appeared that number had barely budged. Neverthe less, some experts think this election might have been a turning point. IT’S ALWAYS DARKEST … Jean Sinzdak, associate director of the Center for American Women and Politics CAWP , is one such expert.

5-chunk_137_-7043284604568589421.chunk_text: Jean Sinzdak, associate director of the Center for American Women and Politics CAWP , is one such expert. CAWP is a unit of the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey. Sinzdak oversees many of the Center’s programs, including the Ready to Run® campaign training program, which encourages and prepares women to run for elected office. She is realistic about the 2016 results.

5-chunk_138_-3053637216035332474.chunk_text: She is realistic about the 2016 results. “The numbers are essentially stagnant in terms of the proportion of women serving in state legislatures, which is unfortunate. ” Depending on outcomes of the undecided races, there will be 24. 7 to 25 percent women in state legislatures nationwide, up from 24 percent.

5-chunk_139_-4388146293361453875.chunk_text: 7 to 25 percent women in state legislatures nationwide, up from 24 percent. “We’re still figuring out what happened,” said Sinzdak. “One factor is that 785 of the women running were challengers — that is, trying to unseat an incumbent, which is very difficult. ” Incumbents win about 90 percent of the time because they have a record, they have name recognition, and they know how to raise money.

5-chunk_140_6475804355041388524.chunk_text: ” Incumbents win about 90 percent of the time because they have a record, they have name recognition, and they know how to raise money. Men and women have different motivations for running for office, and this difference, contends Sinzdak, makes the statehouse an excellent fit for women interested in politics. “When we survey men and women legislators, the number one reason men run for office is career advancement. ” Women tend to run be cause they care about a particular issue.

5-chunk_141_-8090784021750089647.chunk_text: ” Women tend to run be cause they care about a particular issue. They want to have an impact, and there are tremendous opportunities on the state level to have an impact. “Yes, people pay attention to national politics, espe cially during a presidential election,” said Sinzdak, “but so many policy decisions are made at the state level — decisions about the environment, education, pub lic health, transportation. We’re always encouraging women to get involved.

5-chunk_142_5246955627732273285.chunk_text: We’re always encouraging women to get involved. ” Sinzdak pointed to the accomplish ments of two New Jersey state senators — Loretta Weinberg, a Democrat, and Diane Allen, a Republican — who in 2008 co sponsored a bill designed to make the procedures of the powerful county political parties more transparent and fair. Other laws sponsored by women in the New Jersey state legislature include a requirement that insurance companies pay for at least 48 hours of hospital care for new mothers and a law making human trafficking a crime. There is another reason Sinzdak is cautiously optimistic that the nation may be starting to edge closer to gender parity in elected office: “This year we have a record number of registrations for our Ready to Run campaign training program.

5-chunk_143_-1999485601557058267.chunk_text: There is another reason Sinzdak is cautiously optimistic that the nation may be starting to edge closer to gender parity in elected office: “This year we have a record number of registrations for our Ready to Run campaign training program. ” The Center’s partners around the country also offer the program, but CAWP’s is the largest, and every year about 150 to 200 women participate. She pointed out, “In December, about five women are usually registered; this year, there are 75. This is encouraging.

5-chunk_144_8334355533526241403.chunk_text: This is encouraging. I think it shows an upswing of interest in politics and government — in running and helping others run. VERTICAL VS. LATERAL

5-chunk_145_4070711999526475114.chunk_text: LATERAL “Winning a seat in the state legisla ture can be an entry point for women Jean Sinzdak, associate director of the Center for American Women and Politics, a unit of the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey. and a stepping stone to higher office,” said Barbara Palmer, Ph.

5-chunk_146_461414545320315417.chunk_text: and a stepping stone to higher office,” said Barbara Palmer, Ph. D. , associate professor of political science at Baldwin Wallace University in Berea, Ohio. An expert on congressional elections and the success of female candidates, Dr.

5-chunk_147_-571711582184260262.chunk_text: An expert on congressional elections and the success of female candidates, Dr. Palmer is the founder and executive director of the Center for Women and Politics of Ohio, a nonpartisan organiza tion devoted to providing information about women who have run for public office in Ohio. The state legislature pipeline ebbs and flows with the status of women in society and the national and state political landscape, as Dr. Palmer details in the first chapter of her book, Women and Congressional Elections: A Century of Change .

5-chunk_148_-2952692666977138353.chunk_text: Palmer details in the first chapter of her book, Women and Congressional Elections: A Century of Change . Of the 55 women elected to the U. S. House between 1916 and 1956, only 10 had served in the state legislature because law — the profession from which most state legislators were traditionally drawn — largely excluded women.

5-chunk_149_61026308866443571.chunk_text: House between 1916 and 1956, only 10 had served in the state legislature because law — the profession from which most state legislators were traditionally drawn — largely excluded women. However, between 1956 and 2010, of the 191 women elected to the U. S. House, 94 49 percent had served in a state legislature.

5-chunk_150_-5590033697050147049.chunk_text: House, 94 49 percent had served in a state legislature. “The idea is, you get political experience, then you move up. The skills you acquire at the state level — campaigning, creating a law and moving it through the process — are transferable,” she said. “It’s relatively rare for someone with no political experience to become president.

5-chunk_151_5191391061740428627.chunk_text: “It’s relatively rare for someone with no political experience to become president. ” According to a CAWP survey, more than one third of women serving in the state legislature said that seat was the first one they ever ran for. “It’s a good place to start, if you choose to take that route,” said Sinzdak. “Women often assume they have to start at the bottom — town council or the school board, for example — and work their way up.

5-chunk_152_-6302079097730946800.chunk_text: “Women often assume they have to start at the bottom — town council or the school board, for example — and work their way up. This is really not the case. Politics and gov ernment are very fluid, and people move around a lot. We encourage women not to think of a political career in terms of climbing a ladder.

5-chunk_153_9103442004015679838.chunk_text: We encourage women not to think of a political career in terms of climbing a ladder. ” More crucial to a woman’s success in winning a state legislative seat is understanding her district and plan ning a campaign based on answers to questions such as: What is the majority party in my district? Will I need to chal lenge an incumbent? Do I have a base of support and name recognition?

5-chunk_154_-528137234577881356.chunk_text: Do I have a base of support and name recognition? Will district demographics work in my favor? State legislatures around the country vary greatly in size, structure, rules, power, professionalism, and accessibility. Campaign strategies must take these differences into account.

5-chunk_155_8657507546576179608.chunk_text: Campaign strategies must take these differences into account. As Dr. Palmer pointed out, “The single biggest obstacle to women run ning for office and getting elected is incumbency. ” When the Ohio state legislature enacted term limits in 1992, it was thought that restricting representa tives to four terms of two years each and senators to two terms of four years each would create opportunities for women.

5-chunk_156_8167754652413268253.chunk_text: ” When the Ohio state legislature enacted term limits in 1992, it was thought that restricting representa tives to four terms of two years each and senators to two terms of four years each would create opportunities for women. “This turned out not to be the case,” she said. “After 1992, we’ve held steady at around 20 percent. Now we’re up to 25 percent.

5-chunk_157_9072228739821585846.chunk_text: Now we’re up to 25 percent. There is no obvious pattern, but we have not seen the kind of steady increase we’d expected or that we’ve seen in some other states. ” Of course, incumbency can work in a woman’s favor. Dr.

5-chunk_158_2622710535678079531.chunk_text: Dr. Palmer points to Jo Ann Davidson, who represented Franklin County in the Ohio House from 1980 to 2001. She held many leadership positions in the state legislature, including assis tant minority whip, minority whip, and minority leader. She was the first woman elected Speaker of the Ohio House, and in 2005 she was elected co chair of the Republican National Committee.

5-chunk_159_-5793264824188111892.chunk_text: She was the first woman elected Speaker of the Ohio House, and in 2005 she was elected co chair of the Republican National Committee. WOMEN IN THE BAY STATE Christa Kelleher, Ph. D.

5-chunk_160_-3737057883117766384.chunk_text: D. , is research and policy director of the Center for Women in Politics and Public Policy, McCormack Graduate School of Policy and Global Studies, at UMass Boston. Having observed Massachusetts politics since she was a teenager, she sees stag nation in the number of women in the state legislature, which in Massachusetts has been just around 25 percent since the 1990s. “That’s pretty disturbing,” said Dr.

5-chunk_161_-3494289191701010015.chunk_text: “That’s pretty disturbing,” said Dr. Kelleher. But she thinks the percentage is about to change, pos sibly moving closer to 30 or 33 percent. “Research shows that one third is an important percentage in terms of critical mass.

5-chunk_162_6752888298739964955.chunk_text: “Research shows that one third is an important percentage in terms of critical mass. When women are surrounded by other women, a positive dynamic hap pens, and they have a greater impact. ” In Massachusetts, as elsewhere, there is also a pattern of incumbency, which affects women, who may be facing ad Christa Kelleher, Ph.

5-chunk_163_4546853688609340703.chunk_text: Christa Kelleher, Ph. D. , research and policy director for Women, Politics, and Public Policy, McCormack Graduate School of Policy and Global Studies, UMass Boston. Barbara Palmer, Ph.

D. , associate professor of political science at Baldwin Wallace University in Berea, Ohio, and executive director of the Center for Women and Politics of Ohio.
